title: Fast Coflow Scheduling via Traffic Compression and Stage Pipelining in Datacenter Networks
abstract: Big data analytics in datacenters often involve scheduling of data-parallel jobs. Traditional scheduling techniques based on improving network resource utilization are subject to limited bandwidth in datacenter networks. To alleviate the shortage of bandwidth, some cluster frameworks employ techniques of traffic compression to reduce transmission consumption. However, they tackle scheduling in a coarse-grained manner at task level and do not perform well in terms of flow-level metrics due to high complexity. Fortunately, the abstraction of coflow pioneers a new perspective to facilitate scheduling efficiency. In this paper, we introduce a coflow compression mechanism to minimize the completion time in data-intensive applications. Due to the NP-hardness, we propose a heuristic algorithm called <italic>Fastest-Volume-Disposal-First</italic> (FVDF) to solve this problem. For online applicability, FVDF supports stage pipelining to accelerate scheduling and exploits recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to predict compression speed. Meanwhile, we build <inline-formula><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\sf Swallow}$</tex-math><alternatives><mml:math><mml:mi mathvariant="sans-serif">Swallow</mml:mi></mml:math><inline-graphic xlink:href="wang-ieq1-2931716.gif"/></alternatives></inline-formula>, an efficient scheduling system that implements our proposed algorithms. It minimizes coflow completion time (CCT) while guaranteeing resource conservation and starvation freedom. The results of both trace-driven simulations and real experiments show the superiority of our algorithm, over existing one. Specifically, <inline-formula><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\sf Swallow}$</tex-math><alternatives><mml:math><mml:mi mathvariant="sans-serif">Swallow</mml:mi></mml:math><inline-graphic xlink:href="wang-ieq2-2931716.gif"/></alternatives></inline-formula> speeds up CCT and job completion time (JCT) by up to <inline-formula><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.47 \times$</tex-math><alternatives><mml:math><mml:mrow><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mo>.</mml:mo><mml:mn>47</mml:mn><mml:mo>×</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math><inline-graphic xlink:href="wang-ieq3-2931716.gif"/></alternatives></inline-formula> and <inline-formula><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.66 \times$</tex-math><alternatives><mml:math><mml:mrow><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mo>.</mml:mo><mml:mn>66</mml:mn><mml:mo>×</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math><inline-graphic xlink:href="wang-ieq4-2931716.gif"/></alternatives></inline-formula> on average, respectively, over the SEBF in Varys, one of the most efficient coflow scheduling algorithms so far. Moreover, with coflow compression, <inline-formula><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\sf Swallow}$</tex-math><alternatives><mml:math><mml:mi mathvariant="sans-serif">Swallow</mml:mi></mml:math><inline-graphic xlink:href="wang-ieq5-2931716.gif"/></alternatives></inline-formula> reduces data traffic by up to 48.41 percent on average.
